trans-unit.source: Setting up PowerShell for Resource Manager templates
trans-unit.target: Setting up PowerShell for Resource Manager templates

trans-unit.source: Before you can use Azure PowerShell with Resource Manager, you will need to have right Windows PowerShell and Azure PowerShell versions.
trans-unit.target: Before you can use Azure PowerShell with Resource Manager, you will need to have right Windows PowerShell and Azure PowerShell versions.

trans-unit.source: Verify PowerShell versions
trans-unit.target: Verify PowerShell versions

trans-unit.source: Verify you have Windows PowerShell version 3.0 or 4.0.
trans-unit.target: Verify you have Windows PowerShell version 3.0 or 4.0.

trans-unit.source: To find the version of Windows PowerShell, type this command at a Windows PowerShell command prompt.
trans-unit.target: To find the version of Windows PowerShell, type this command at a Windows PowerShell command prompt.

trans-unit.source: You will receive the following type of information:
trans-unit.target: You will receive the following type of information:

trans-unit.source: Verify that the value of **PSVersion** is 3.0 or 4.0.
trans-unit.target: Verify that the value of **PSVersion** is 3.0 or 4.0.

trans-unit.source: If not, see [Windows Management Framework 3.0](http://www.microsoft.com/download/details.aspx?id=34595) or [Windows Management Framework 4.0](http://www.microsoft.com/download/details.aspx?id=40855).
trans-unit.target: If not, see [Windows Management Framework 3.0](http://www.microsoft.com/download/details.aspx?id=34595) or [Windows Management Framework 4.0](http://www.microsoft.com/download/details.aspx?id=40855).

trans-unit.source: You must also have Azure PowerShell version 0.9.0 or later.
trans-unit.target: You must also have Azure PowerShell version 0.9.0 or later.

trans-unit.source: If you have not installed and configured Azure PowerShell, click [here](powershell-install-configure.md) for instructions.
trans-unit.target: If you have not installed and configured Azure PowerShell, click [here](powershell-install-configure.md) for instructions.

trans-unit.source: You can check the version of Azure PowerShell that you have installed with this command at the Azure PowerShell command prompt.
trans-unit.target: You can check the version of Azure PowerShell that you have installed with this command at the Azure PowerShell command prompt.

trans-unit.source: You will receive the following type of information:
trans-unit.target: You will receive the following type of information:

trans-unit.source: If you do not have 0.9.0 or later, you must remove Azure PowerShell using the Programs and Features Control Panel and then install the latest version.
trans-unit.target: If you do not have 0.9.0 or later, you must remove Azure PowerShell using the Programs and Features Control Panel and then install the latest version.

trans-unit.source: See [How to Install and Configure Azure PowerShell](powershell-install-configure.md) for more information.
trans-unit.target: See [How to Install and Configure Azure PowerShell](powershell-install-configure.md) for more information.

trans-unit.source: Set your Azure account and subscription
trans-unit.target: Set your Azure account and subscription

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have an Azure subscription, you can activate your [MSDN subscriber benefits](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/) or sign up for a [free trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have an Azure subscription, you can activate your [MSDN subscriber benefits](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/member-offers/msdn-benefits-details/) or sign up for a [free trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).

trans-unit.source: Open an Azure PowerShell command prompt and log on to Azure with this command.
trans-unit.target: Open an Azure PowerShell command prompt and log on to Azure with this command.

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you can list your Azure subscriptions with this command.
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple Azure subscriptions, you can list your Azure subscriptions with this command.

trans-unit.source: You will receive the following type of information:
trans-unit.target: You will receive the following type of information:

trans-unit.source: You can set the current Azure subscription by running these commands at the Azure PowerShell command prompt.
trans-unit.target: You can set the current Azure subscription by running these commands at the Azure PowerShell command prompt.

trans-unit.source: Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct name.
trans-unit.target: Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct name.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Azure subscriptions and accounts, see [How to: Connect to your subscription](powershell-install-configure.md#Connect).
trans-unit.target: For more information about Azure subscriptions and accounts, see [How to: Connect to your subscription](powershell-install-configure.md#Connect).

trans-unit.source: Switch to the Azure Resource Manager module
trans-unit.target: Switch to the Azure Resource Manager module

trans-unit.source: In order to use the Azure Resource Manager module you will need to switch from the default set of Azure commands to the Azure Resource Manager set of commands.
trans-unit.target: In order to use the Azure Resource Manager module you will need to switch from the default set of Azure commands to the Azure Resource Manager set of commands.

trans-unit.source: Run this command.
trans-unit.target: Run this command.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You can switch back to the default set of commands with the **Switch-AzureMode AzureServiceManagement** command.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You can switch back to the default set of commands with the **Switch-AzureMode AzureServiceManagement** command.
